questions.question: What is pathology?
Which of the following is NOT included in the study of disease as presented in the lecture?
What does the term 'etiology' refer to in pathology?
Which of the following is considered a predisposing factor in the etiology of disease?
What is the direct cause of a disease known as?
Acquired exciting factors can be classified as exogenous and endogenous. Which of the following is an example of an exogenous factor?
Which of the following is an example of an endogenous exciting factor?
Which of the following statements is true regarding congenital factors?
options: They are never caused by environmental factors

questions.question: What is the difference between congenital and hereditary diseases as described in the lecture?
options: Congenital diseases are inherited while hereditary diseases are not
Hereditary diseases result from in-utero exposure while congenital do not
Congenital diseases are due to in-utero factors while hereditary diseases are genetically inherited

questions.question: What does 'pathogenesis' refer to in the context of disease?
options: Mechanism through which the cause produces disease

questions.question: In pathology, what does the term 'gross picture' refer to?
options: Visual inspection of tissue changes with the naked eye

questions.question: What is examined under the microscope in pathological analysis?
Which of the following is NOT a method used for microscopic examination in pathology?
What is meant by 'lesion' in pathology?
options: The structural changes in tissue due to disease

questions.question: What does the fate and prognosis of a disease refer to?
Which of the following best describes complications in pathology?
What is the purpose of a biopsy in pathological investigation?
options: To examine a tissue specimen during life

questions.question: Which type of biopsy is performed using imaging guidance?
What is autopsy in the context of pathology?
Cytology is best described as the examination of what?
A patient with low immunity who later develops an infection exemplifies the interaction between which of the following factors in disease etiology?
Which pathological investigation method is most likely to provide immediate intraoperative diagnosis to guide surgical decisions?
In evaluating a tissue sample, a pathologist uses various staining techniques. Which stain is mentioned in the lecture for examining paraffin or frozen sections?
How do immunohistochemical methods enhance microscopic examination in pathology?
options: By identifying specific antigens in tissues

questions.question: In the context of pathology, what does the term 'lesion' specifically denote?
options: Any structural change in tissue as a result of disease

questions.question: According to the lecture, which sequence best outlines the components included in the study of a disease?
options: Definition → Etiology → Pathogenesis → Pathological pictures → Fate & Prognosis → Pathological investigation
Etiology → Pathological pictures → Definition → Pathogenesis → Fate & Prognosis → Pathological investigation
Pathogenesis → Definition → Etiology → Fate & Prognosis → Pathological pictures → Pathological investigation
Fate & Prognosis → Pathological investigation → Definition → Etiology → Pathogenesis → Pathological pictures

questions.question: In the investigation of a disease, why might an ultrasound-guided biopsy be preferred over a surgical biopsy?
options: It provides a larger tissue sample
It is more accurate in identifying genetic disorders
It avoids the need for H&E staining

questions.question: How do predisposing factors contribute to the development of diseases?
options: By creating conditions that favor disease development
By always leading to immediate disease onset
By acting as the sole cause of disease

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a hereditary factor in disease etiology?
What distinguishes cytology from biopsy in pathological investigations?
options: Cytology examines tissues while biopsy examines cells
Cytology examines cells while biopsy examines tissues

questions.question: Which method is NOT typically used for microscopic pathology according to the lecture?
The term 'exciting factor' in pathology is best described as:
options: The factor that predisposes a person to disease
The direct cause that triggers the disease
The factor that determines the outcome of the disease

questions.question: How might hypersensitivity serve as a predisposing factor in disease?
options: By weakening the immune system against infections
By causing an exaggerated immune reaction that may damage tissues
By increasing the blood supply to tissues

questions.question: In the context of pathological pictures, which observation would most likely be classified as a gross pathological change?
options: Tissue color change visible without a microscope

questions.question: Which of the following statements about pathogenesis is most accurate?
options: Pathogenesis is solely responsible for the clinical symptoms
Pathogenesis describes the series of events leading from the cause to the disease manifestation
Pathogenesis is only relevant in genetic diseases

questions.question: How does pathological investigation differ from the study of prognosis?
options: Pathological investigation is performed during life while prognosis is determined after death
Pathological investigation involves methods to examine tissues and cells, while prognosis predicts the disease outcome
Pathological investigation only uses imaging techniques, whereas prognosis only uses biopsies

questions.question: Which scenario best illustrates the use of pathological investigation in clinical practice?
options: Determining the cause of death through autopsy
Identifying the mechanism of disease development
Predicting disease complications without tissue examination
Observing the gross appearance of a tissue sample

questions.question: Considering the role of tissue staining in pathology, what is the primary purpose of using H&E stain?
options: To differentiate between various tissue components
To measure the electrical activity of tissues
To guide surgical removal of tissues

questions.question: Which combination of pathological components is essential for a comprehensive understanding of a disease, according to the lecture?
options: Gross pathology, Microscopic pathology, and Cytology
Definition, Etiology, Pathogenesis, Pathological pictures, Fate & Prognosis, and Pathological investigation

questions.question: A complex case study requires integration of all aspects of pathology. Which of the following approaches best demonstrates a comprehensive pathological assessment?
options: Focusing solely on the microscopic picture

Integrating the disease definition, identifying etiological factors, understanding the pathogenesis, evaluating both gross and microscopic pathological changes, and considering the prognosis along with appropriate investigative techniques
Relying exclusively on imaging techniques for diagnosis
